Only in a Hawaiian restaurant is it endearing (and not tacky) when your server comes around, holding her baby while taking your food order ;)

Seriously though, Island Flavor is legit! True Hawaiian food at its best!!! I found this restaurant through Yelp and it is worth the (less than) 20 minute drive from the strip. 

My boyfriend & I split the Furikake Poke, while he opted for the Fried Rice Omelet with Portuguese Sausage and I got the combo with KFC (Korean Fried Chicken) and Teri Beef.....Omgaaaah, so delicious (or should I say "ono"!) The portions were monstrous, but most importantly, the food was amazing. I have been craving REAL Ahi Poke and I'm so glad I got to have my fix here! Huge chunks of fresh Ahi Poke sprinkled with Furikake mmm, it was perfect. I have also been on a Korean Fried Chicken kick recently, and Island Flavor definitely got it right. So crispy, juicy and garlicy! The Teri Beef was great quality (not thin or stringy at all) and the sweet sauce was the clincher. No lie, everything we ate was amazing....even the Mac salad and Guava Juice!

I am definitely going to try to come here next time I'm in Vegas :) Now seriously, can we get a Hawaiian joint as good as this in So Cal? Enough L&L, I want an Island Flavor haha!

Blade Runner (Deckard is a Replicant!), City of Lost Children (augmented senses or whatever used and abused and mostly, well, just giving us far less than what we might dream of), andDark City: These really ought to be added.For a while now, I've been waiting for an animated film that might affect me as much as Miyazaki's stuff has. This one is the 1st.Hmm, scratch the "animated" part of that.I have an intense love-hate relationship with film noir and, hey, if you don't leave, it must be mostly love, right? But, there are so many sci-fi and noir themes totally submerged in this film that it's just a wonder to watch.These people did an incredible job!

The reason why people say that this movie scared them is because it did!! That means the movie purpose was felt by a few who did see it. When I first saw this Movie it scared me and made me think about life and religion. This is not a blood and gore scary type movie, but the kind that you would think that it may be possible for things to happen the way the movie was written. Of course non believers will say its only a sci-fi movie. Truth is, this movie is a must have for your thriller collection, even if it does have a religious view. If you are a fan of classic thrillers (Omen..etc) this is one of them and its a must have. I never saw the sequel (Distant Thunder), but I believe it picks up where this movie ends.
Brilliant food, wide range of drinks ( both alcoholic and non), great atmosphere, good selection of music, excellent service, need I say more?!

rallys dude drove here drunk last sunday. me and burd ordered some blt's and i said \"gimmie ur largest order of onion rings my man!\" we were sitting there chowin down when all of a sudden a brawl broke out. luckily they were throwin broomsticls chairs and razor wire (only at each other dude)i had my mace can but fired it backwards out accident as i tried firing indiscriminately. shot it in my bug glasses sorry dude.

Very nice korean restaurant located at Holiday Villa Hotel. Be there early as there is a queue! The cheesy korean dish will be sold out so be sure to make a reservation for it. Can do it via FB PM. However, reservation of dish is not the same as reservation of a table. The cheesy dish turns out to be underwhelming. The chicken was more flour than chicken. The other dish like garlic soy chicken was good!

Singapore to Bangkok. The crew organised a surprise birthday celebration for my wife on board the airplane. The crew were friendly, caring and helpful and offered their own donuts to my wife to represent it as a cake. My family are so grateful to their kind hospitality. Keep it up! Tigerair will be my first priority for my next destination. Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

My wife and I recently spent a long weekend at the Ames. We received a warm welcome on arrival and check in was smooth and quick, even though we arrived a few hours before official check in time our room was ready. The room, a junior suite, was very modern, clean and spacious. The bathroom was one of the biggest I have ever seen at a city hotel and was bigger than the total size of some rooms I have stayed in. There was a separate seating/lounge area with sofa's, table and chairs, desk and TV. The room was at the front of the hotel and we did get quite a lot of noise from the street, but it's right in the city and some noise can be expected. Anyway, it didn't keep us awake, but I sleep heavy so if you are a light sleeper I would suggest you request a room at the side/back.
Complementary breakfast was a selection of bread and fruit with coffee. The atmosphere in the breakfast room was very laid back and casual, which was great, but be aware the menu is very limited and if you want something more substantial you will need to go and find it somewhere else.
On the whole a great stay, we enjoyed this place.

My husband and I stayed at this property during a quick 3 day trip to NYC. Check in was quick and easy, the staff member (Christine I think) checking us in was very friendly and efficient. The hotel itself is very pretty with the lobby area hosting a great bar with a VERY nice bartender. The drinks were great, and the ambiance perfect.
We also found the rooms here to be a great size for being in the city, it was a much larger and much better appointed room than rooms we have had in other local hotels.
If you are at all interested in shows the concierge (Adam) was incredibly helpful, he spent about 20 minutes with us giving us honest opinions on his favorite shows, calling ticket brokers, making reservations, etc. We received excellent seats to a great show and were very happy with all the work he put into our evening. He also had excellent recommendations for dinner reservations and called to make them for us. Amazing service thanks Adam!!
Overall, great property, great stay and we would definitely stay here again!
I've been coming to Kimi for a while, my lashes are always perfect and I get a lot of compliments! Everyone asks me where I got em done. She's the best!

this hotel was AMAZING best hotel I have ever stayed! from the moment you pull up in front of the hotel everybody is very welcoming right away they open your door & get your bags. The staff shows you where everything is located, they are very nice. The room is perfect i loved the tv in the bathtub, the cute patio outside, the ipad, the bed feels like heaven! And everything you need is on the touch screen phone room service, if you want to turn off the lights its so cool. The pool is heated which is great. And the food wow! so good the pancakes & orange juice were my favorite so fresh & organic. The hotel feels like paradise you must stay here at least once in your life, because I can honestly say there is nothing negative to say about this hotel! I am definetly coming back this is the prefect quiet get away.

I bought a box of 8 for my coworkers, and I'm now up for promotion!\nSeriously though, these chocolates were amazing. Cherie and John are great, and really know their stuff. The care and attention to detail they put into their work is inspirational. I will definitely be back.
i am feeling somewhat more energetic and have rediscovered some strength in my major muscle groups
I LOVE that place in Vegas especially for breakfast. Seafood Crepe is AMAZING!!!!\nHighly recommending this place!!!

This is our little diamond in the rough! If you want the easy going crowd and feel of a neighborhood bar, the prices and drinks of a dive bar, the cleanliness and customer service of of a more upscaley spot then come check us out! Everyone who pops in always comes back and at the very least you won't be disappointed! You can count on getting a pretty smile helping you at all shifts of the day! A nice and chill morning shift, a Rockin day shift and a spot on drama free night! Come check out the best little hide out on the west side tucked away by the car wash! Consider this post the magic word, mention to Summer (me) and let the good times roll!!!

This hotel was pretty nice for the most part. The staff was great and always helpful when ever you have a question. I stayed in a 2 room lakeview suite on the 17th floor(top floor). My suite had 2 double beds and a queen size pull out couch, microwave, mini fridge, coffee maker, and 2 sinks. The suite was very nice with the exception of the fan in the restroom which did not work. After looking up at the ceiling to see the air vent I could clearly see why the fan did not work. There was at least 1 inch of dirt and grime covering every portion of the vent. Nothing went in or came out so it wasnt any bother to me. Other then that the room was great and the beds were comfortable. The lakeview we had was very nice. We were fortunate enough to be there on a Wednesday night when at the Navy Pier they shoot off fireworks. We sat in the luxury of our room at had a 100% un-obstructed view of the fireworks.
The two things I would have to say sets this hotel apart from others is the package I had came with valet parking and hot to order breakfast each morning for everyone in your party. The parking alone would have cost at least $40 per day. The hot to order breakfast each day was great. They will make eggs, omlets, biscuits and gravy, sausage, bacon, pancakes, potatoes, etc......
There is a store named Dominicks right across from the hotel for any of your needs incase you forget something, need beer, etc... You can also buy passes there for the trains and buses.
Navy Pier is about a 4 block walk from the hotel and is great for an early morning walk or jog along the lake.
Overall I would recomend this hotel to others. It is in a great location to everything and the rooms are decent. I would stay there again in a heartbeat!
just good and fun and good to listen to songs in the background.

Everything was perfect - food (both breakfast and dinner), atmosphere, service, music, drinks. Couldn't expect more. I paid attention to the freshness and quality of the food they serve. High five for high quality!

I make a call to this shop inquiring a particular bouquet I was interested in after seeing it on their website. The young lady who answered was very welcoming and they helped me each step of the way as I decided what flowers I wanted to go with. I would strongly recommend this shop for their friendly and quality service. \n\nI spoke to Paula. She'll take very good care of you.

The name of this property changed in 2012 from an InterContinental Hotel to the Royal Sonesta. No fears, this hotel remains a gem! Excellent location and wonderful staff! Large, clean, well-lit and functional rooms with comfortable beds! Above average fitness room, featuring more than just a few cardio machines. (The vending machine in the fitness room, I'll admit, made me laugh as it included M&Ms, Doritos, Coca-Cola and more not-so-healthy choices, among other offerings.) Try the on-site restaurant; despite its lame name, The Restaurant, dinner was very good, and not too over-priced for an on-property restaurant. Must admit, some of the best hotel staff I have ever encountered at one property. Have to give credit to Reese (front desk), Sergio (car valet), and Yashar (concierge lounge) - each was friendly and professional, well deserving of a pat-on-the-back for jobs well done. Encountered air conditioner and TV issues upon check-in; each was immediately fixed! Definitely will be back!!

Yes the room was nice...and yes the location was perfectly convenient. But what gives this place 5 stars and knocks it out of the park are the people that work there. Two in particular i'd like to point out because by the end of our stay, they felt like friends. Jo jo the bartender at the restaurant was not only attentive and great at his job...but went so above and beyond to make our visit (we went twice) to the restaurant one to remember. They make fabulous bellinis...go hit him up for some of those! And finally, Serge the manager. I don't think i've ever met a manager that attentive and dedicated to making sure that his guests were happy.
Overall, during out 3 night stay, on several occasions, random folks working at the hotel would ask how we were and if they could get us anything. AWESOME!
check out the little shop in the hotel...i found an awesome pair of earrings at literally jaw dropping price! never woulda thought i could find that at a little hotel gift shop! hahaa.
The Spa was great. I got a pedi and i wish i remember the name of my aesthetician...it was very relaxing. The Spa only gets a 4 though bc it was quite small...but service was great.
If you're staying on the Riverwalk...this is the place!

Great place to pick up breakfast/lunch/snack! Super convenient if you are staying at the Bellagio in the Spa Tower. Ate a delicious ham & cheese panini (the mustard was awesome!) for lunch. Also had half a nutella crepe and a bite of a chocolate strawberry crepe, both were delicious! Throughout our stay I also tried a smattering of pastries for breakfast throughout the week (apple brioche, blueberry brioche, apple muffin, raisin cinnamon roll), all were excellent. I also bought the peanut brittle as a gift and they gave a nice bag to put it in. Avoid going at peak times, as the line can wrap around the counter.
Melisa T, helped me to clarify all my doubts and she guided me in very detailed manner.

Stayed her for four nights in early October 2008. Like many was a little concerned by reviews citing small rooms etc.
The Not So Good... Room IS small by US standards but good for NYC. Bathroom also small (but this allowed my wife to stay in bed longer while I got dressed!)
Window mounted aircon unit a little unpredictable and view uninspiring (onto an internal courtyard). Location is a little scary at night.
But...
The Good... Hotel staff very friendly and helpful (as was all the New Yorkers we met). Big bed (by our standards) Flat screen TV. Good cross-section of guests - airline staff, business people etc. The scaryness of the location is more in your head than in reality - provided you take the normal sensible precautions that most people do. Location is great - short walk to Times Square etc and spoilt for choice with eateries on 9th Avenue.
Take the opportunity to talk to the locals and see how really friendly they are - after all you are not going to stay in your room all day are you?!
Hotel rooms in NYC ARE expensive (we had a higher class room at Dupont Circle in DC later in our trip for less than we payed in NYC) but the WJ provides a good, clean safe base for a short trip.
I wasn't looking forward to staying in New York and saw it as a necessary evil before moving on to Washington DC. But my wife and I are already making plans to return in two years time and will probably stay again at the WJ or similar - the Waldorf Astoria being a little out of our league!
PS:The lift/elevator - everything you've read is true! We walked down at all times!
You can be in the heart of downtown Chicago, with a suite and continental breakfast for a little over a hundred dollars. I was completely satisfied.

The food is still so similar to my early visits here around 2007 when they were still in Mid Valley. Great vegetarian food. Only difficult thing is to get parking. Probably best to use some form of ride sharing to get here.
Price is a little more than I care to pay but good service. No complaints

This review might have some of the same information as the one from Thornhill, below, becasue that one was written by my son after the first night. Now that we've completed our 4 night stay, here's the full scoop.
This hotel is ideally located on a quiet side street within easy walking distance of Broadway, Times Square, 5th Avenue stores and Rockefeller Center.
It is a converted apartment building but that doesn't matter - the rooms are standard, comfortable, nice sized hotel rooms (except the bathrooms - which are ridiculously small). The staff from front desk to door man are exceptional. They just can't do enough and they do it all quickly with a smile on their faces.
Here's what you need to know before booking the Belvedere:
1. Top floors have been recently renovated with new beds (very, very soft) and luxury linens, larger and newer TV's. But, because you are on a higher floor, your windows are in the open air meaning you hear every bit of traffic - horns, sirens, etc, that come from the major NYC streets below. And these go on continuously, all day and night. The lower floors facing the back (we were on the 6th after we moved from the 14th) have no view at all and back onto another apartment building. This insulation means we didn't hear any street noise at all from this room. A QUIET ROOM WOULD BE A LOWER FLOOR, CENTER OF THE BUILDING, FACING THE BACK.
2. The washroom is tiny. Don't plan on displaying any toiletries.
3. Blow dryer - awful. Call the front desk and the they will bring up a very powerful handheld blow dryer.
4. Elevators can be slow - there are service elevators on either side of the hallway. Use them.
5. There's a fridge and microwave in each room which are great for snacks and drinks. The little store on the corner has very reasonable prices on fresh fruit, drinks, etc.
6. The Conceirge is fabulous. She has great ideas and a lot of up to date information on restaurants, attractions etc. In fact, she told us to avoid an area restaurant because they had just changed chefs the week before and there were still a lot of kinks in the food and service. Her recommendations were great.
All in all, this hotel is very clean, comfortable (in the right room) and a great value for the location. It's not luxury by any means but it's a nice place to come back to after being out all day.

We were in Seattle for a leisurely weekend. The location of this hotel was terrific. It was within walking distance of Pikes Market and a fairly level walk as well. It was within walking distance of the monorail which was very convenient for our visit to the Space needle and surrounding areas. There were a lot of wonderful restaurants to choose from. The hotel was very busy hosting a convention while we were there so other than it being difficult to get an elevator at times, it was actually quite quiet and didn't seem claustraphobic at all. The service level was still maintained. The room we were in was very clean, comfortable and we had a spectacular view of the city. The staff were attentive and pleasant. We have stayed here once before on the club level and really enjoyed it. We will be back.

I am sure regular rooms are not so large, but I stayed in a double with 2 bathrooms!! That allowed my adult daughter and my husband and I to stay together and no waiting for the bathroom. Beware that they have double beds..........very cozy indeed when used to a king. The room was quite large, had a desk and sitting chair, small view of the lake. I ignored the ceiling paint peeling in the bathroom cause it is an old hotel.
Very close to shopping. There is an El stop outside one of the doors. To get to the airport (if you don't need help with the luggage), 2 blocks down the street is the BLUE line which goes to O'hare airport, way cheaper than a cab, and weekdays a safer bet getting to your flight on time. It takes about 30 minutes.
Drawbacks, seems a charge for everything now. Want a fridge/ $$ Gym? $$. On the internet do not try to change your reservation; like the airlines they will revert back to the current rate and you essentially rebook. I had to leave a day early and it was no problem at the front desk keeping my good rate. Front desk staff and concierge helpful as were the doormen.
The lobby is very busy afternoons and nighttime, worth sitting for a refreshment and watching the world go by. The refurbishment of the lobby back to its former glory is fantastic.

21 Bistro found near the start of Chinatown has array of local Chinese & Western food.I generally love their array of local & seafood! There was a local band singing Oldies but goodies of the past...ambience was just great as we were carried with the flow of music...and happy feet tapping away.Basically the Boss of the place is here every night to mingle with the crowd and it seems very homey where almost everyone knows one another.If you are in Kuching do drop by...it's a happy place for a drink or bite.

We stayed at the Tuscan Inn for 2 nites in June 2004 and found it quite appealing. A superb location, reasonable price, easy access to all the main sights and transit lines to get around the city. Clean and well-appointed rooms were a bit smallish for a family of four, (we used a King, sofa bed and rollaway), but as one previous reviewer indicated, we spent most of our time out and about. Excellent staff and service and the adjoining Italian restaurant was superb. A very nice lobby. A very cheerful staff and prompt service. Highly recommended!
Happy birthday to my lovely wife, we ordered Mexico Chicken, Honey Oat Chicken & Chicken Tikka. All taste delicious üòãOverall: I visit frequently, nice and cozy restaurant.

This Residence Inn was located right off of the highway near restaurants and even a movie theatre. It isn't one of the newer hotels, but for the price, it was well worth it. I had a problem with my room, but after I spoke to the front desk employee....I think her name was Bailey?, the problem was immediately resolved and she went over beyond to make sure my stay was a positive one. This hotel is very lucky to have employees like this.
I will stay here again when business brings me back to Ft. Worth!
respectful, careful

Chose this hotel because of the good reviews on Trip Advisor For a recent 3 night trip to Philadelphia and was not disappointed. The property is in a great location within walking distance to all of the historical sites, Old Town and the great shops and restaurants along South Street. The hotel restaurant and lounge were excellent with fantastic service, would highly recommend the pulled pork or the Cheesesteak sandwiches as both were excellent. Our rate included daily breakfast which included a full buffet or menu al a carte items, both of which were great. Will definitely stay at this location when in Philadelphia again.

Thank God for the Detroit Coney Grill! David, the owner, is super friendly and is on top of his business. My wife & I ordered 3 Coney dogs with mustard, fresh cut onions, and topped with a sweet chili, that was a nice bean less meat sauce. The hot dogs were hot, expertly grilled, not steamed! The buns were warm, fresh and steamed. The Detroit dogs were excellent! When you bite into them, they have a nice snap. Everything was just like what we grew up eating back east in CT & MA. \n\nWe also had a bag of Detroit Better Made potato chips and 2 bottles of Faygo root beer pop. We drove down from North Scottsdale and the trip was well worth it. We do hope David can open a spot up north, closer to our home. We give it an A+. We will come back again! Best of luck to David, the owner. Keep up the good work!
Food is fab but service was very slow, maybe coz it was a huge crowd being served by a small team.

Our group had a block of rooms booked for the YCOA National Cheerleading competition. I was concerned after reading some of the previous reviews. For the price we paid, I was not expecting the Ritz. We had one of the former smoking rooms and there was a strong smell of disinfectant. No elevator. No fancy flat screen TV's. The internet worked great. The rooms were dated and they need to invest in some new bedspreads but it was clean and comfortable. The pool and hot tub were nice and well used with 8-14 year old cheerleaders. The girls loved it. They all had a great time.
My only complaints were that they only supplied one bath towel in the room for two people. Also, there is a mexican restaurant across the road that played loud music until 3AM on Saturday. This is ok if you want party but not if you are trying to sleep. So if you are considering stay here on a Saturday night, ask for on the north side of the building.

Overall, I was pleased with my stay at the Westin. My wife and I have stayed at several hotels in Boston and have always liked the Weston. While its not the Boston Harbor Inn, it is very nice and priced reasonably given its location. Only complaint was that I had asked for an early check in and while not guaranteed, they have always accomidated me in the past. Normal check in was 3:00 pm and we arrived at 12:30. Because the Red Sox had played a playoff game the night before they were sold out and behind. They took my cell number and said they would call when it was ready (1 to 1 1/2 hours they told us). We came back a little before 3:00 and it still wasn't ready. Without even asking the desk clerk had the floor manager come out and found us another room that was on the 24th floor (we originally had one on the 32nd) and appoligized for the trouble.
The environment is good, but the food is a bit greasy.

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place! The lunch specials are awesome- pizza or sandwich of your choice with any salad of your choice for under $10! I highly recommend trying the caprese bowl for your appetizer, it is RIDICULOUSLY DELICIOUS! It's a deconstructed bowl full of home-made burrata mozzarella, pesto, cherry tomatoes, drizzled with olive oil and balsamic vinegar, served with a crisp artisan bread (so good I dream about this menu item!) The pizzas are served on a delicious, crisp, brick oven style sourdough crust... I have tried the SOP (it was ok) the Roasted Mushroom (Yum!) and the Fig and Prosciutto (AMAZING!) The salads are also delicious!

Such a wonderful night out - food was so good! Staff were friendly and helpful, made the whole experience even better. It was my mum's birthday - so glad we decided to come celebrate here! Will definitely be back! :D
Food delicious. Good service. A good place for family dining.

Outstanding hotel with a great location in a great city. Very clean and comfortable. Nice sized room and bathroom. Right off Michigan Ave and an easy walk to Lake Shore Dr to Navy Pier. Staff makes it a point to address you by name. They even sent champagne and strawberries up to the room for our anniversary. My wife loved the shopping situation right inside the building. Very convenient. Gloria, in the general manager's office, was especially kind and helpful. We would definitely stay there again.

My husband and I live here in San Antonio and were seeking an inexpensive way to spend our Valentine's Weekend. Check-in was very quick and easy with no hassles whatsoever. Our AAA rate was honored and an additional $18.50 was assessed for the hotel's valet parking service. Since the hotel is located in a very convenient location, we parked our vehicle and did not need it again until we checked out. We were assigned room 225 which has a queen sized bed. The room, although small, was very clean and comfortable. The bathroom was absolutely spotless. The shower's water pressure was more than adequate although the water temperature did fluctuate back and forth from hot to cold to lukewarm. Amenities included in the room were the usual hairdryer, an iron/ironing board and in-room coffee maker (single use filter packets). The television was an older tv. Being that the pay-per-view movies were $15.99 each, we had hoped the tv would have been an updated, better quality, flat screen tv. Needless to say, we saved the money and took a walk instead. The Crockett Hotel is VERY close to several local attractions. It is located directly behind the Alamo, adjacent to RiverCenter Mall and only a short walk to the RiverWalk. Market Square is an approximate 10 minute walk as well. Breakfast is included from 6:30 a.m. - 9:30 a.m. Unfortunately we missed that window so I can't comment on how it was. Overall, the hotel was very nice with a great location. We will definitely consider staying at the Crockett again for a weekend getaway and plan on recommending the Crockett to out of town friends as well.

The Sheraton Boston hotel is centrally located. Their club floor lounge is awesome with amazing city views. The club floor is open 24/7 with an awesome cappuccino machine and complimentary water bottles etc. It's a nice upgrade to splurge for the club floor considering it includes continental breakfast and free wireless access.
This hotel is connected to the prudential center mall and just a couple of blocks from the T and trendy Newbury street. This hotel is close to Boston University and many other universities.Parking is pricey at about $44/night, but it is about the same at most Boston hotels and there is no street parking.
The hotel is clean, well kept etc. Everyone that worked there was very helpful. I have stayed there several times and the Sheraton Boston is a reliable, consistent choice.
All in all, the Sheraton Boston hotel is a nice choice for the area.

Best Damn Haircut Ever. Grade: A+

Imma be blunt: Fellas, stop wasting your time & money on talentless hacks (the 99.9% of people who cut hair) & make this guy your regular.

This guy puts everyone else in the haircutting game to shame. Male, female, gay, straight, black, white, young or old...they all suck compared to this Italian-American dude. He is a true artist & even has a mini-statue of Michelangelo's David next to the chair (a very cool reclining chair) for inspiration or as a reminder that you're going to be walking out of there looking like a masterpiece.

Called ahead on rainy Saturday & left with the best haircut I've had in years. Hip but not hipster, classic handsome good-looking cut. All done with minimal direction from me (take the sides & back in, comb the front forward & give it some height). I went home, inspected his work & it was flawless 360! Not one missed spot (usually, for me, behind the ears), & not one follicle left untended.

Incredible attention to detail, very friendly intelligent funny guy (when he was done, he said, "Well, I've done enough damage to you...What do you think?"), good conversation & casual vibes, all for $14...

Just. 
Perfect.

#ItaliansDoItBetter

I am King of All Bad Haircuts no more.

Stayed here 31st March for four nights on our first trip to New York. Took the two bedroom family room in the upgraded part of the hotel - this had one large twin bedded room (no door!) and a seperate adequately sized room with queen bed. Very clean and comfortable. Equipped with two fridges with complimentary water and coke, which was a surprise. Both rooms had amazing views of the Empire State Building. The breakfast was a bit of a 'free for all' and served up on plastic plates and cutlery, however, it was more than adequate and set you up for the lenghty sightseeing ahead! Fantastic location, less than 10 minute walk to Times Square, subway on the corner and buses nearby - very easy to commute around Manhattan from here. Three Irish pubs all within 50 yards! All in all, an excellent hotel and would have no hesitation in returning - preferably soon, New York is a special place! One last mention for the roof terrace - unfortunately the bar was not open due to weather being on the cool side, but the view of the Empire State Building was something else!

In a better civilization, this and many other of the David Suchet movies would be released in theaters. The plots are fabulous (no, I'd no clue who had done it, but the clues were all there if I'd been more imaginative - the best kind of mystery), the production values astounding, the acting (from Edward Fox, Sarah Miles, Lysette Anthony, Megan Dodds, and of course David Suchet as Hercule Poirot) simply perfect, the dialogue wonderful, the music and sens of suspense and tension just wonderful stuff.One of the pleasures of these Hercule Poirot movies for a man is how many beautiful women star in them! Here were have two - the sexy sinuous Megan Doods and the stunning Lysette Anthony.You really can't go wrong renting these - they're just wonderful - like the most wonderful dinner in the most wonderful restaurant with the most perfect company you can imagine - your mind constantly working because it's all there and you struggle but by keeping your mind constantly thinking can keep up with everything - and the settings gorgeous.I can't think of movies that stimulate thought more than these Hercule Poirot/David Suchet movies. It's impossible to over-praise them - and I had never seen one before a few months ago nor read an Agatha Christie.

So good and the staff is awesome! I like the pizza and salad.

My new husband and I stayed at the Ritz for our wedding night. The hotel was immaculate, and the staff was wonderful, we were treated like royalty from the moment we arrived. Our executive suite was amazing, we were on the 12th floor, and the champaign and chocolate covered strawberries we requested were waiting for us on arrival. There were rose petals all over the suite, leading into the bedroom, then forming a heart on the bed, which was a really nice special touch. We had two bathrooms, the master bathroom was huge, in marble and stone, with a tv built into the mirror. Bed was amazingly comfy. Uptown charlotte views were great, with the floor to ceiling windows. We snuck a peek at the gorgeous pool and hot tub on the top floor, also.
The BIG flaw is that the hotel is right across the street from the Epicenter, home to lots of bars and nightclubs. All we heard all night (until about 3AM) were police sirens, drunken people screaming, and loud base, coming from the night clubs. I couldn't fall asleep until everything shut down, even with the tv on in our room. I dont want to say that ruined the night, but it definitely had a huge negative impact.
The other minor glitch I feel is worth mentioning is that we booked under a bed and breakfast package deal, so breakfast was supposed to be included, yet sure enough, when we checked out, they had charged us for breakfast, so we had to have them take it off. To me, that shouldnt have happened, it's pretty easy to see that breakfast is supposed to be included.
I would recommend this hotel to others but ONLY if they were coming on a non-weekend night.

This restaurant was truly excellent. Loved just about everything about it. Came here once months ago, do not know why I have not been back yet!

Our server was very nice, it was my first time there and she took time to answer my questions fully and such. I ordered a pizza that seems to no longer be on the menu? Wondering if maybe the stuff on it is just out of season or something, because I'd be so sad if it is permanently gone! I got a pizza with butternut squash, marcona almonds, goat cheese, some sort of leafy green, a swirl of balsamic, and marcona almonda. I am completely obsessed with pizza, especially unique pizzas, and The Parlor makes a mean pizza. I inhaled the whole thing in what felt like minutes.

Planning on coming back and introducing The Parlor to my pizza-loving family members to see what they think!

Starbucks has become the most popular coffee shop in the world, exhibiting true staying power. Opportunities in international markets should allow Starbucks to maintain double-digit growth for many years to come.

The show was so hilarious and funny, I almost peed in my pants and I was on stage! My sisters and I had some time to kill and after spending almost $2,000 on other shows (Love, Barry Manilow, etc) I wanted to be entertained but without costing an arm and leg. I went on Yelp and read the reviews on Mac King. I went to the show and we had the best time ever. I wonder why he isn't a headliner somewhere...maybe he will be after he keeps getting rave reviews. I can't wait to go back and take my daughter and her boyfriend. I already alerted all my friends, you will not be disappointed. His magic acts are amazing...AMAZING, and he is soooo funny, we were rolling in the aisles. Going to this show really made our trip to Las Vegas so much fun. Wish there were more shows like Mac's.

Denpasar to Yogyakarta. Overall quite satisfied but seat comfort is the main issue. I can't deny that I went for the cheapest tickets. Online booking was easy. Online check-in opens 24 hours before the flight and I was able to already select seats for free which was nice. Check-in and baggage drop-off at Denpasar Bali airport was quick. We booked 15kg of baggage, one bag was slightly overweight and I didn't bother too much beforehand. The employee weighed the two bags together and it said 29.2kg so no problem at all. I printed online boarding passes but we got new ones at baggage drop-off. Flight boarded nicely on time, about 10 o'clock before the 10.25 departure time. Pushback was at about 10.30 and takeoff just shortly thereafter. According to schedule, flight-time would be only 55 minutes and landing would be at 10.20 (Java time is one hour before Bali), but we landed at about 10.40. Taxi took only a minute and 10.50 we were waiting inside on our luggage. That took about 15 minutes to appear on the belt, maybe a little long. The flight itself was boring. There is no service available. Flight attendants seemed professional though. The seat was the main letdown. A little filthy and legroom insufficient. Should have been the same 29 inch pitch as on AirAsia but felt tighter. Couldn't keep my legs straight with my 1.92m and had to bend them. Because of the short flight it was doable but I would try to avoid this seat on longer flights. I would fly Lion Air again on short flights. Our flight operated nicely on time but I hear that can also be an issue.

The straighteners were delivered very quickly and packaged well. Received the free brush (bonus). This is a gift though so I haven't used the item yet. It's been on the Christmas wish list for a long time though so I hope I get brownie points!

Paul Rudnick (Jeffrey, Addams Family Values) wrote this frothy tale of a mild mannered school teacher (Kevin Kline) who is outted on the Academy Awards by a former student-turned-actor (Matt Dillon). The rest of the film deals with the absurdities revolving around this setup -the effect on the town, his fiancee (Joan Cusack), himself- and climaxes with an everybody-loves-everybody finale. If you're an angry gay rights activist or a naive youth looking for an accurate portrayal of a man's struggle to come out or a 'true' depiction of gay life, then save yourself the trouble and rent something else (maybe Beautiful Thing) or read a book (Giovanni's Room). If you are able to understand that this film was inspired by the piousness of Tom Hanks's speech on the Academy Awards when he won for Philadelphia and pokes fun at Hollywood culture and small town ignorance and you have a fondness for '30's screwball comedy (Bringing Up Baby, Holiday, The Palm Beach Story) then enjoy! Far from being a biting satire, the film tries for the exuberance of a Preston Sturges farce and comes damn close. No, it's not 'deep' or 'powerful' -neither were Romy & Michelle, 9 to 5, or Young Frankenstein- and it doesn't pretend to be; it keeps it's tongue-firmly-in-cheek. It gets too preachy and maudlin for its own good toward the end and sure some of the jokes are a bit stale (there's also a locker room scene that could have been cut) but after sitting through countless comedies that misfire, it's like a breath of fresh air. Kevin Kline and Tom Selleck are wonderfully game while Debbie Reynolds and Wilford Brimley add fine support. The excellent Joan Cusack's award winning performance is stellar and the great Bob Newhart is, well, Bob Newhart. The fact that many have been offended by In & Out is as absurd as the mentality of the townsfolk it pokes fun at; personally, I was more offended by Philadelphia. I'll take harmless fluff over sanctimoniousness anytime.

Having a actual person in the normal help yourself buffet was wonderful. The girl at the front desk was also very helpful, calm and efficient. I am only sorry we didn't get these girls names. The Channel Inn is in a really awesome location. It's right on the water and they have FREE parking, something unheard of in DC. We walked to the Smithsonian and to a show at the Warner Theater. Easy, fun walk.
The rooms are old looking, but if you are like me, and have plans to do things all day, all you really need is a comfy bed to come back to.
Gripes include:
1. Unfriendly staff
2. Construction was being done while I was there, and the workers started around 7:30, hammering away at the room next to us. They were also right outside of our room walking around on the roof
3. As soon as I get to any hotel I put the " DO NOT DISTURB" sign out on the door handle. We got a knock on the first morning there at 9:30 asking if we needed fresh towels. No, obviously, I don't. The second morning, departure day, we got a knock at 10:15, "Are you leaving today?" Which I'm sure they know that we are with a list of check-out's given to them in the morning from their manager's. It's a minor gripe, but I just like being left alone when I'm away.
Will definitely return. Great price and location.
A great amenity they really need is mini fridges!
I would give it five stars but the sound is a little off otherwise great selection of music and podcast!

We've stayed at many Courtyards - this one is a bit off the beaten track but it's a good location if you're staying in NW San Antonio.
Everything was clean and the staff friendly but the hotel looks like it's due for a refurbishment. All the fixtures and furniture looked a little tired. It's in a very diverse neighborhood and there are a number of small ethnic - Tai, Indian, Middle Eastern - restaurants. That was a nice plus since most Courtyards are surrounded by chains. There is also a Starbucks close by which was good because the hotel coffee needed a make over too.
Be sure that your room does not have a door to an ajoining room. Ours did - and the baby in the room wasn't sleeping through the night.
We'll stay again when we have business in the NW Medical center area because the location can't be beat.

Nice little restaurant tucked away in Bukit 0Pantai. I was greeted by Sam, a bubbly and very helpful staff. He made me feel pampered, and I was looking for being pampered as well. 5 stars for service.Started with a glass of prosecco and acqua panna. Sam served the Foccacia quickly. And it was perfectly toasted, one of the best I have had. Wanted to finish the plate but had to resist the temptation as I have save stomach room for what is to come.Had the Mangiare 21 quarter chicken to start, as I did not see anything appealing for starters. And it was a delicious chicken. Lots of flavours and roasted to perfection. Some may find the flavours a little strong but after a few bites, it becomes nice.Then I had the spinach ravioli which was superbly made and cooked in a tangy and Creamy tomato based sauce. Couldn't stop eating even though I know there is still the tiramisu coming. Compliments to the chef for this fantastic dish.

Our family of 6 stayed in a 2 bedroom apartment for a week in June. The accommodations were top notch. A full kitchen, washer, dryer, flatscreens with great sound system, and a fantastic view of the bay!! The modern furnishings were quite appealing to us, as were the daily chocolates left in the room....
The complimentary house car was great for trips to the grocery store or other places within their 2 mile radius. The drivers were very pleasant young men, helpful and accommodating. We used the hotels's bikes to ride across the Golden Gate Bridge and explore a bit, a very nice time. Cable Car stop was close by.
Breakfast was ok. The food choices were fine, but the buffet was not restocked often enough to accommodate the late risers. The afternoon wine time really should be extended for another hour so that guests have a bit more time to enjoy....I'm thinking that something more like the lounge options at the Waldorf or Ritz Carlton properties would be appropriate for a property such as this.
As nice as the hotel is, the outdoor section of Ghirardelli Square is a bit depressing....lots of empty storefronts...just seems a bit run down....perhaps due to the current economic conditions.
Some of the family activities we enjoyed:
Dylan's Tours (full day including Muir Woods) Fantastic!!!!
Alcatraz
Yank Sing for dim sum twice....my mouth waters just thinking about it.
running and biking along the marina and over the Golden Gate Bridge.
All in all, a nice stay....

We were in vegas for the Sema show, looked up the best ramen and this ramen house came up. All four of us agreed.....it is the best! We had all the ramen options and loved them all. You can order them hot or regular...both ways are totally yummy. Fried rice if good but order it light oil. Pork belly bowl is bomb. We ate there 3days out of 5....it was that good. Options get expensive though. Enjoy!

Stayed at the Philly Courtyard recently with my family. Perfect location for site-seeing being right across from City Hall and walking distace or very short cab or bus ride to all the historic sites. Also, 1 block from the Reading Terminal Market and the wide variety of food available there. No shuttle from airport to hotel, but with four people we took a cab and it was a reasonable cost and a quick ride. Very comfortable beds, large room, mini fridge, flat screen TV, good sized bathroom, no dinging elevator noises, no loud groups bumbling in at 4am and only heard the street noise once -- obnoxiously loud motorcycle. All in all a whisper quiet hotel given the locaton right next to city hall on an extremely busy street. I would ask for an upper floor though. We stayed on 11. Highly recommend this hotel for tourists, but seemed like when we were leaving on a Monday, business people were checking in. We didn't use room service or the hotel bar or restaurant. Pool was very small -- only negative. Would go back for sure. Beautiful building. I did not park(no car), but noticed it was $38/day...seemed a little expensive to me.

Five fingers of death: Although previous Shaw Martial Arts epics had shown the influence of the American cowboy genre, none had paid such open tribute to it as this one, especially in the saloon fight scene. And though Shaw Bros. films had borrowed from the Japanese chambara (swordfight) genre before, none had done so with such success as this one. i suppose some of this had to do with the fact that the director originated from Korea, and thus brought a non-Chinese perspective to such borrowings, which certainly raises some interesting questions about culture; but in any event, this film presented real innovations in technology and technique in Hong Kong action films. for the first time in Hong Kong, the camera was given access to the whole of any given set, which meant shots from many different angles, such as the low-angle interior shot showing the ceiling of a room (the original American innovation of which usually credited to John Ford), or the high angle long shot that allowed visualization of a large ground area, or the frontal tracking shot.It is true that this was not the first hand-to-hand combat film of real cinematic substance - that remains Wang Yu's 'Chinese Boxer'; but on a commercial level, Shaw Bros. were right to choose 'Five Fingers' as their first major release to the West because, one might say, it was the 'least Chinese' of their action films, that is, the least dependent on purely Chinese theater traditions. Although this made no impression on the American critics at the time (who universally trashed the picture), it wasn't lost on American audiences, especially among African Americans, whose culture had always been - by necessity - an eclectic patchwork of borrowed elements and innovation. In 'Five Fingers' they were given the opportunity to discover the core of the story, in the earnest young man forced to make the extra effort to overcome social barriers and betrayal in order to have his merit recognized. This seems to be an issue universal to Modernity, but each culture has its own way of expressing and resolving it; 'Five Fingers' presented it in a way many Americans could relate to as well as Chinese.So is the film now only of historical value? Certainly not. For one thing this issue hasn't gone away. Secondly, some of the innovations leave much of the film looking as fresh today as it did on first release. Also the action is well-staged, and the performances, though a little too earnest, are crisp. The film is a might over-long, but the story does cover a lot of ground. And there are marvelous set-pieces through-out, such as the saloon confrontation, the fight on the road to the contest, the odd double finale.definitely looks better on a theater screen, but still impressive for home viewing: recommended.

Got a great price in advance for a Red Premier room on the top floors with a fabulous strip view, pool, Eiffel Tower, Paris Balloon, and all. My boyfriend and I spent a couple days in Planet Hollywood and a couple days in Paris just to get a couple different vibes and hotel experiences - and we ADORE Paris. We're in our mid and late 20s, and many have said this is more of a place for elderly folks to stay, but we sure enjoyed it much more than Planet Hollywood.

The room was a little on the small side, but I loved the decor. The different patterns and materials never clashed. Just watching the Bellagio fountain shows over and over and over from our windows on the adorable, cozy sofa was enjoyable enough to make the choice worth it. 

The restaurants were great and I enjoyed everyone we encountered that did us even the smallest service. Vallet, front desk, bellman - everyone was funny and kind, which is a great, relaxing contrast compared to how overly and unnecessarily rude and brute a lot of workers for taxi lines and clubs in Las Vegas are. That shit gets old REALLY fast and it's great to go to a peaceful, welcoming, romantic and cheesy spot that's also a big part of Vegas' allure.

DAD's bagels is my life-saver. Emergency breakfasts, nothing for lunch? A fresh straight out of the wood-fired oven bagel cannot be beat. When I get them hot I usually eat them straight out of the bag, and rarely get fancy with anything more than some whipped cream cheese.

If, on rare occasion, I am unable to get the hot bagels, I will toast them lightly and use them for a sandwich. The bagels at DAD's are more substantial than your usual Montreal bagels, so they hold up well to being packed with smoked salmon, some ham or even some sliced chicken. 

This shop also sells ready to reheat indian food, several pastries, sandwiches and a few other. almost random, items. Whenever I have shown even the slightest of interest in any of their Indian foods, they end up giving me something. I don't know. What I have had has been really good, but I've never actually bought (paid for) any of their Indian foods. 

I rarely buy anything but the bagels and cream cheese, but sometimes, if I am stuck for breakfast, I know I can buy eggs, or cream, or bacon, or juice. Very convenient as they are open 24/7.

They've got my vote for the best bagel in Montreal.

A few years ago I stayed at the Beacon Hotel (just a couple of blocks down Broadway from the Milburn) right after it reopened following a major renovation. It was then really cheap and I loved it. Especially the kitchenette (in every room)--I'm one of those visitors to New York who likes to shop for and eat the same foods New Yorkers do: fruit, pastries, deli take-outs, bagels, etc. etc. This requires somewhere to store food and preferably some plates and utensils to eat with. So the Beacon was great, but it has become way too expensive for me. I consider myself very lucky to have now found the Milburn. Same great location for groceries--Zabar's is just north on Broadway, Fairway just south! And kitchenettes! OK, so the kitchenettes aren't quite as good as the Beacon's. You do, however, get a fridge, a microwave, a sink and some basic dishes. And you get a clean room, a mostly renovated bathroom (for some reason, probably cost, they chose to put in new sinks and tile but not new toilets or tubs or shower tile). Great central air conditioning. And a very spacious room. For (in my case), less than $200 per night. And free breakfast is included--with real New York bagels, good pastries, better than average coffee, yogurt, fruit, toast, etc. What a deal! Only downside: the mattress was way too soft. If I had stayed longer, I would have asked to change to a room with a firmer bed.

I was at the Churchill Washington DC from Aug 17-Aug 24, 2009. I had a wonderful experience from the time I checked in to the time I left. The check in/check out was very fast and efficient. The room was very pretty looking and quite large. The staff was very helpful in any questions I had about DC since it was my first time there and the bar with the internet cafe was very nice touch. The hotel location is very good too - in Dupont Circle - very nice safe area with a lot of places to eat and the metro is 4 blocks south of the hotel. the hotel is up a hill so bring your walking shoes, but its nothing that bad. i def would stay here again!

I am a HUGE Brazilian BBQ fan and this place is the top of the heap thus far..

The salad bar is the size of a classroom. It has everything you can imagine on it, cheeses, spreads, breads, olives, multiple salads, did I say cheese? You could have a quality dinner just off of it.

Then, the meat comes. I was smart enough to avoid the temptation to stuff myself from the salad bar and wait for the steak and it was worth it. Just some of the best meats Iv had in a while..

And , for reference, lets talk about how the meat is cooked: OVER A FIRE. If you want something well done, thats towards the outside. If you want it rare (bloody for me), that will be on the inside. If you don't tell the guy who's carving which you want, you'll get whatever happens to be next in line on the chopping block. So don't complain about the steak being over/under cooked, just pipe up and tell them what you want. 

Deserts were equally as wonderful. We had one of each on our table of about a dozen. Top it off with an espresso and I was ready and willing to take a long nap in a hot tub.

For the money (it's a few bucks more than Samba) do yourself a favor and take a cab down the strip and eat here. And make sure you're hungry.

My daughter goes to college in SF, and I found this place by accident online (location/price combo). I have stayed here 4 times now. It is a quirky place, and as we know if we like the quirks we find them charming, and if they don't they bug the hell out of us. Some of these other reviews indicate as much.
The location (just above Union Square) is unbeatable. The structure is an old 6-floor building that doesn't seem to to have been updated for ages. (This hotel has been family owned and run for decades. They live here still.) Again, I don't mind that the furniture looks like it came from a 1940s rummage sale. You might. There is charm everywhere here including the elevator which dates back to like 1915.
The staff is pleasant but decidedly hands off. Though I have stayed here 4 times in the past 6 months, they have no idea who I am or that I have been here before. That's a little weird. But it's okay. :-)
The rooms are of radically different size and are grouped (and priced) accordingly. The small rooms are barely (barely) big enough for one adult person. Don't be cheap and try to put two people in one of those (despite the fact that it'll say "Queen bed"). If there are two of you, get a large room. The large rooms are decent size -- downside is, they have awkwardly packed in too many pieces of the rummage sale furniture which makes the room feel crowded still.
Breakfast is free (except for the tip) and fast (no menus, french toast or eggs, plus juice and coffee). I only eat it 1/2 the time because it's too early for me (7:30-9 weekdays; 8:30-10 weekends) but for those here on business I guess you're up and out anyway so why not. They also offer free wireless internet which is very cool.
I am a total priss about getting my sleep, and let me tell you I sleep great here no matter where my room is. And I nap in the late afternoon too. Yes you can often hear the city outside, including the cable car bells over on Powell, but it's a cool noise, and as I say sleeping is easy.
So ultimately I would say, if you are looking for super-modern amenities and outgoing personnel, this is not the Hyatt. But if you want something from a somewhat lost era, with some old-world charm, stay here. (I am writing this from my room -- I check out today!) And I'll be back... even if they don't remember me!
We were staying at the Datai and visted this Restaurant many time, is world class, totally outstanding, with great service, the menu is excellent.

I just returned from a 3 day, 3 night stay at the Biltmore (Wed - Sat) and I think there were tears in my eyes when I pulled away last evening! It was truly a pleasure from the moment I checked in until I left. I paid in advance for a deluxe resort room in the Valley wing which was large with a lovely balcony overlooking Camel Mountain to the left and the large lawn and a glimpse of the Paradise Pool to the right.
I was travelling alone (woman, mid 30s) and the staff made extra sure I was comfortable regardless of what I was doing. They remembered me from the front desk, to the restaurant, to the pool. Normally when I travel, I use the hotel for sleeping only, this was not the case for this vacation. The only time I left the resort was when I went shopping on Friday at the Biltmore Fashion Park (free shuttle service) and the Fashion Square (5 miles down on Camelback Rd).
Two of the evenings I ate on the outdoor patio of Wright's Bar and was able to order food from the Grille. I also spent 2 full days in a cabana by the pool where the staff were attentive and lovely and I also had a terrific, relaxing massage at the spa one of the early evenings.
Because I was there mid-week through the weekend, I noticed a huge difference in clientele. Mostly business men and women Wed-Fri and then families on the weekend. The pool was much livelier on Saturday and I recommend splurging for the cabana to escape from the noise and sun if necessary.
I loved my stay here and would recommend it to single travellers or families. I hope to return for many more vacations.

Nauru to Pohnpei. Small but friendly airline. The seat configuration was 3+3 and the legroom was OK for my 6ft frame. No real in-flight entertainment. On the relatively short-haul island hopping, only snacks were served but there was beer and wine. We made a reservation at Brick Tops for Queen's Feast. The table was ready for us when we arrived early, our dining partners were held up in traffic and were 15 minutes late. Restaurant Week is a busy time for many of the nice places in Charlotte, but we were treated to the superior service and fabulous food we have enjoyed in the past, even though it was Restaurant Week and they were very busy. We were not rushed at all, the food was perfectly cooked and we had a relaxing and enjoyable meal. PLUS, we could hear each other speak at the table. We could actually have a conversation! This is so rare today with all the restaurants doing nothing to quiet the sound. I would pick Brick Tops any time we want a nice meal out with friends. Absolutely loved it and so did our friends who had never been there. I will sing their praises to anyone who will listen!

Man oh man what can I say. First of all, reading all these negative reviews makes me so sad! I absolutely love this place and adore the owners and Ace, the sushi chef, he is incredible! I have been coming to Kokoro for the last year practically every Wednesday for lunch and I have never been let down! Every person I bring with me or suggest to come on their own would agree with me. The food is always fresh, service is timely, I'm always greeted by a friendly face, and their restaurant is always clean. I always look forward to my Wednesday lunch date with Kokoro's sushi. I usually order Edamame, the Las Vegas Roll, and the Caterpillar Roll. When my friend comes with me she usually orders the Honey Sesame Chicken or the Teriyaki Chicken. Both of our meals are a hardy helping and we are both satisfied and full when we leave. I can't tell you how obsessed I am with their Las Vegas Roll. I consider myself a sushi connoisseur of sorts. I've lived in the Phoenix/Scottsdale area for 10 years now and have tried many sushi spots. Kokoro, hands down, has the best Las Vegas Roll in the valley. I will continue to recommend Kokoro sushi as one of the best places to get sushi in the Phoenix area!

Once in the Life means that once a hoodlum, always a hoodlum, and nobody gets in or out of `The Life' for free. Neighborhood hoodlums in New York sell drugs and run scams because they can't make it in the legitimate world, maybe because they have a criminal record, or a drug habit, or because they're just lazy. This simple story with a couple of twists about mostly despicable characters manages to draw compassion out of the audience for its main players because of their loyalty and compassion for each other. The film is written, produced, and directed by Laurence Fishburne, who also stars as 20/20 Mike (all hoodlums have nicknames), and is based on his play, `Riff Raff.' It feels like a play from beginning to end, especially during the longest scene where the three main players square off to decide who can be trusted. Often times the dialog comes very fast, much faster than it would on stage, and I think it's the film's biggest flaw. Mixed in as flashbacks throughout the film are poems from the street, a sort of iambic pentameter rap, that is violent and evocative of the world this movie discloses. The poetry makes it difficult to dismiss these men, these hoodlums who murder, cheat, and betray each other, as unworthy of our attention or below our contempt. The disturbing thing about this film is that its realism shows us not only how these people live, but how they suffer for the same reasons as us all. One is too stupid, another a junkie, and the last suffers from conscience while the audience wonders, or even laughs, at the irony of executioners demanding from him hanging in the gallows to tell jokes in the midst of his demise.

What makes this one better than most "movie movies" is that it doesn't feel phony. The film the story of the hot-headed director and his rise and fall and rise, by using real recognizable names and events during the silent and early sound eras. Instead of the generic "sound will put us out of business" business, they actually SHOW Jolson and "The Jazz Singer". The acting is really quite good, with believeable performances from Don Ameche, Alice Faye and J. Edward Bromberg in particular.

This is the only full length feature film about the world of bridge. I found the first 10 minutes a bit slow, but after that, the movie is absolutely perfect in describing professional bridge players and how they go about earning a living. Some of the scenes are very funny. I don't think that a non-bridge player would get the charm of this movie. Some of the dresses are really beautiful, pity the movie is in black and white - I can only imagine what they would look like in colour. The way the media are portrayed is absolutely hilarious. There is no way on earth bridge will ever be like that. Watch it as soon as you can, and tell your friends about it.

I have read many of the other reviews and am in agreement, esp. about the weird bathroom window shutters and slatted door. All bodily function sounds are shared into the sleeping area. Wonderful pool on the 7th floor. Apples in the lobby and near the pool and exercise area. Clean, clean, clean!!! Concierges were GREAT.. I cannot say enough about each of them. A good rate is no good if it's a bad place but the Geary Parkway Motel made saving money quite nice. We saw other travelers just like ourselves there, and that increases your comfort.

Bottom line: we'll stay there again.

Michael Haight was the attorney my chiropractor recommended when the insurance company of at-fault driver in my auto accident refused to pay my treatment costs. I was wary at first, but went to my consultation, and immediately felt at ease. 

Steven Shulman was assigned to my case, and dealt with me expeditiously and professionally. He learned the unique situation of my case, and was able to use that to help obtain an optimal result. Although we were not able to settle my claim easliy due to issues with the insurance company, Steve made the deposition and arbitration process easy and tolerable. 

Even down to the payment of my final settlement check, everyone at Henness and Haight was courteous, professional, returned calls promptly, and took the time to get to know me as a person, not just a case. I am indebted to them for their superior service, and am proud to be (as Mike Haight put it) "a part of their family." Although I hope that I will never need to use their services again, I am grateful for the representation I received and would highly recommend them to anyone in need of a personal injury attorney.

Okay. Here's the deal. Enough of the froo-frooness of some of these reviews and the sheer audacity of others.
Cut to the chase: CALL BEFORE YOU COME to notify them you are coming in late or that you WANT THE ROOM ON THE SECOND FLOOR (you are adults and should be doing this anyway before you visit a hotel to make sure they even have your reservations.)
-Politely ask for a room on the top floor- minimizing overhead foot traffic.
-the contintental breakfast is a "Sam's Club" danish and some juice/coffee/hot cocoa. So what. it's not as though you're paying $200 a night for this place. it's a mom and pop thing (when they are there- that's later) they aren't chargin' for parking, so take that money and have a nice breakfast down the street.
-the parking spots are narrow. however, when we were there and every room was filled, and people couldn't park right, we were allowed to park in one of two handicapped spots. there are more spots than rooms.
they can also make a phone call to have someone come and re-park their car, if you ask nice.
-Because the photos don't show it, what this place is is, well picture an three layered oval (uncovered in the middle) (like a doughnut) the top two layers are rooms. the doors open up into the middle. the lowest level is where you park. so, if an idiot sets off his car alarm or some parents don't teach their children to respect hotels and use their "inside" voice, yes you can hear stuff. but i don't think it is nearly what people are making it out to be.
-this hotel is pretty much near everything you want. 2 blocks to the trolley which will take you pretty much everywhere. it will also take you to the bus line for places further out.
-the mom and pop who are there most of the time bring in another gentleman when they go away on family business, trips, etc. they are working too and from speaking with them, a heck of a lot. Now, i DO agree with the fact that they know a little bit more about where to eat, thing to do etc. but the young gentleman i just as good.. just give him some idea of what you want. saying "uh, anything" gives no one a chance.
- the place is clean as a whistle. the rooms are quite large for those of you toting kids.
-the price can't be beat (you've no doubt read about the free parking)
-the pizza place down and around the corner rocks.
i guess just use a little common courtesy and common sense and you'll probaly see it for the money saving gem it is. you get what you pay for. if you are looking for lux, go somewhere else. if you are looking for clean comfort on a budget-- give this place a try!!

They are just one block over from Broadway and Times Square which is great for 2 reasons. 1) It's right near everything!! 2) Because it's one block over, it's just a tad more peaceful. The service is excellent and what you would come to expect from a Westin. The food doesn't disappoint either. The on sight restaurants and bar are great too and this hotel is attached to a movie theater with other restaurants as well.
We keep coming back!

It's great to have this place in the neighborhood. I take my mom here on Saturdays and Sundays and sometimes throughout the week. They are incredibly accommodating as they will adjust any dish and just serve us half a serving (their portions are large). My mom loves the coffee here and has it with a shot of whipped cream. This gives it a creamy taste with just a touch of sugar. Some of their exceptional offerings include the Cuban sandwich, crepes, baby back ribs (there are regulars that will just not miss a Friday night because of them), the hamburgers, and of course the She Crab soup, there are of course many others. Their daily offering of soup of the day is usually good also. There is a list of special brunch items on the weekends, but if you don't like what's there, they will always find something you will love. The staff is very friendly and feels more like family. Not a disagreeable one in the bunch. Highly recommend this place.

ok first off i booked the hudson months back and then read the most awful reviews regarding this hotel, and i was very tempted to cancel my stay. however it went ahead and from arrival to departure 6 days later i can honestly say that the people who give negative reviews may well have there own gripes but i had none...yes its trendy hip cool place to be seen if you're into that way of life but seriously..come on..its a hotel..a crash pad..new york is the city that never sleeps so why stay in your room?..
we were greeted by friendly staff and given our room keycard and pass to bar / club - we didnt use the bar / club, there are so many other places to go, and whenever we passed by it we knew the place wasn't our sort of thing..we had a queen room with air con.. window that opened.. shower and bath and yes its small but its a bathroom!!.. our bed was totally comfy and was made up for us each day.. yes the room is fairly small but it is a bedroom!!.. a hotel is a hotel is a hotel.. its a place to rest your head and wash away the day..come on..its a hotel!!!....... we had a great stay, no problems, flame diner over the road is open 24/7 go over there and eat or get take out and eat in your room.. the mini-bar is pricey.. but whooooo uses one in any hotel they are always pricey!!...the staff, yes some of them are wannabees but do i really care...NO..im happy in my world!!
I would recommend the hudson to any age group-its a great hotel great location great decor and preferable to a stuffy chintz and lace affair any day.

We stayed five nights at the Metro - the bed was a bit on the hard side and the air conditioning too noisy to leave on overnight, but it was clean and the staff very friendly and the location was great just off Broadway and five minutes walk from Times Square - very close to the subway with connections in all directions. The room itself had no view (they put us on the back which was supposedly quieter so all we could see were brick walls) but the view from the roof terrace was compensation enough - a fantastic view of the Empire State Building. The free breakfast was good too - bagels, toast, muffins etc and free tea and coffee 24 hours a day. The public areas are lovely - art deco and very stylish.

I can't begin to tell you how fabulous this museum is. I went on a friend's recommendation, and was blown away by the organization and thoroughness of the displays.

The upstairs level is organized by continent, and each country has its own display of instruments from their region. Most also have a video screen, and as you approach the display, your headset automatically begins to play music from the country. Walk to the next display, and your headset plays the next country's music.

Downstairs there is a room that features many important musicians from past and present. Another room gives you the opportunity to try multiple unique instruments.

This is a fabulous place to take your older children, probably about 2nd-3rd grade is the youngest I would take. There is so much to see, it may take you two visits to see everything!

Definitely a welcoming change of scenery after all the rice and noodles we ate while being in malaysia.

We arrived evening into LAX from a 14 hour flight. Rang the hotel for shuttle pickup , which they advised we would be picked up in 15 minutes , which we were. Reception was friendly and quick. Our room (206) was clean and tidy, bed & bathroom were fine, also the free WiFi was handy. We had to fly out the next day so early to bed. Breakfast in the morning was continental style and all that one needed to start the day. , checkout was friendly and quick. Promptly at 8, our free shuttle arrived to take us back to LAX. Super 8 LAX is a great budget airport hotel, and doesn't pretend to be anything more than that, as the name suggests you are near the airport so there is aircraft flying near by, which we personally didn't mind. We wouldn't have any problem staying here again or recommending it to other people.

Excellent service from start to finish.
Put my item in to sell I was given a price which I was more than happy with, added my details and within a couple of days my pack arrived to send my item in.
It was received and within 2 days the money was paid into my account. They kept me updated and it was a very efficient service.

I had heard of John Garfield, but, didn't know him. I loved this movie. I had never heard of it. I just picked it up randomly. John Garfield is a boxer in the movie. He had been in real life also so he knew his part. He was a fugitive throughout the movie. Someone else killed a man. He character was blamed. He is befriended by a family who has questions and is not quite sure what to make of him. All sorts of minor plots ensue. My favorite was the scary swimming scene in a water tower where the water was deep and one Dead End Kid couldn't swim, AND none of them could get out.John's character saves the day. The Dead End Kids were great as his friends and followers. One of them right to the very end. Ann Sheridan played the family's daughter and John's eventual love interest. She was believable, but not lovable in my opinion-the only weak link in the movie.

First let me say the director has some wonderful use of titles in his establishing shots. I really enjoyed them. I really enjoyed this movie but I got to say next to Pierce Brosnan, Greg Kinear is pretty lackluster. Brosnan melts into this character so well, that it is really hard to remember that this is the same guy that played bond. It also shows his range and depth as an actor. It is kinda of an indie flick and was really nice to see especially with all of the mainstream movies that flood the movies at this time of the year. I found the characters to be well crafted. The twist in the middle I felt was especially good. I also liked how the characters come off realistically. So many times we have in film these caricatures of people that are not really characters but walking-stereotypes... I like the different approaches this movie takes. I think of sideways when I think of this movie but I think this is more watchable and a better movie overall...

I have a gathering with 29 people before and it as compatible for it. The food is nice and tasty but just for me the price is slightly higher than average. The environment is good and clean. The waiter is very friendly. Will suggest others whi love Japanese food.
